movies.title: The Shadow's Edge
movies.reviewText: Wasn‚Äôt expecting Jackie Chan, now in his 70s, to feature so prominently in this, but he‚Äôs here doing Jackie Chan shit. The direction and editing don‚Äôt do him any favors, with tight close-ups and quick cuts diminishing the action somewhat. There‚Äôs a fair amount of good action though and Macau is a pretty interesting setting. The movie is brought down by a ton of added melodrama around the aging villain and his Gen Z orphan gang, and the daughter of Jackie‚Äôs old partner, now also a cop, who Jackie has been secretly keeping an eye on since his partner was killed. The credits seem to hint at a sequel, though I‚Äôm not sure how much longer Jackie can keep banging these out.

movies.title: Sympathy for Mr. Vengeance
movies.reviewText: Apparently I logged this before but watching it again I didn‚Äôt remember anything about it. And a lot of memorable shit happens in this movie. It‚Äôs pretty bleak! The ending is just wild. This is probably the most serious I‚Äôve seen Song Kang-ho, who normally injects his roles with humor. Here he‚Äôs just a man on a mission up until the very end.

movies.title: The Rip
movies.reviewText: This movie is a complete slog until it gets going. The first 40 minutes or so make Den of Thieves look like Citizen Kane. When it finally starts cooking, it‚Äôs mostly a mindless, glossy exercise, stacked with talent, like nearly every other high-profile Netflix original. But it‚Äôs hard to deny this cast elevates even the worst dreck to ‚Äúwatchable.‚Äù This could have been a tight 90 minutes if there wasn‚Äôt so much repetitive dialogue and exposition. Also, how are you gonna cast Scott Adkins and not have him kick all sorts of ass? Completely missed opportunity.

movies.title: Sore: A Wife from the Future
movies.reviewText: This is a horror movie about a woman stuck in purgatory who has to fix a man. Besides being played by a mediocre actor, there‚Äôs very little to indicate the man is even worth fixing. The movie finally starts to get interesting when the woman gives up on trying to fix the man and instead pursues her own interests and happiness but, of course, that doesn‚Äôt last long. Things finally take an inexplicable left turn that left me baffled in the end. This is a good looking movie, shot in beautiful locations, and the woman who plays Sore is very sympathetic. But just as her character struggles to change the man, she also struggles to carry this movie across the finish line by herself. What a frustrating endeavor.

movies.title: Civil War
movies.reviewText: This movie came out a year too early. Who would have thought when it was released we‚Äôd be living through another Trump administration, our neighbors being abducted, gassed, and shot to death. The idea of a civil war seemed implausible at best. Now this movie takes on a whole new relevance. Gorgeously shot and well-acted, I love how it builds this world with very little exposition. Though what we do learn still seems highly fantastical ‚Äî that California and Texas would join forces against the president, that journalists would do anything but be a mouthpiece for the regime, that anyone formidable would stand up for us besides our own neighbors. Another year could see this become even more prescient. Hopefully it‚Äôs final shot most of all.

movies.title: Marcello Hern√°ndez: American Boy
movies.reviewText: There‚Äôs no way his mom didn‚Äôt beat his ass backstage after talking all that shit about her. üòÇ

movies.title: Fackham Hall
movies.reviewText: I found this to be mildly amusing. It‚Äôs a sad state for comedy films if we‚Äôre so desperate for them that people are comparing this to Airplane and Naked Gun. GTFOH.

movies.title: The Getaway
movies.reviewText: A couple good scenes but this otherwise feels needlessly long. I really don‚Äôt get what the big deal was with Steve McQueen. I guess you had to be there.

movies.title: Southern Comfort
movies.reviewText: Basically Predator but with more inept soldiers and a bunch of Cajun hunters instead of an alien. If there‚Äôs a lesson to be learned here it‚Äôs that we should lure a bunch of ICE agents into a swamp and laissez es bon temps rouler.

movies.title: Rental Family
movies.reviewText: This was my favorite film of 2025, so was thrilled for it to come out on digital finally. Filled with moments of joy, beauty, heartache and connection, it moved me more than any other movie I saw last year. I really don‚Äôt get the ‚Äúwhite savior‚Äù criticism this movie is getting. Brendan‚Äôs character is the audience surrogate, and his character is as affected by the people he meets as they are by him, if not more so. This movie only works because he is a gaijin. A Japanese person in the same role would just accept the cultural differences as normal and not have the same impact on their ‚Äúcustomers‚Äù, if any at all. Brendan plays the part with an openness and curiosity that few other actors could pull off. And the girl who plays Mia is wonderful. Still needed a box of tissues on second watch.

movies.title: Pillion
movies.reviewText: An interesting movie, to say the least. Like Secretary with motorcycles. Maybe not. Melling and Skarsgard are both great. I don‚Äôt get the appeal of being a sub personally, but Pillion certainly explores it in depth.

movies.title: Cocoon
movies.reviewText: I was 10 when this came out and today I passed the Brimley/Cocoon Line. That is, I‚Äôm the same age as Wilfred Brimley was the day Cocoon was released. This such a fun and wholesome movie. Steve Guttenberg is so charismatic. ‚ÄúFavorite actor Dennehy.‚Äù Surprisingly athletic performances from the three main leads. I hope I can make it to the Ameche/Cocoon Line.

movies.title: A Midnight Clear
movies.reviewText: An interesting follow-up watch with Joint Security Area. Similar situations but we get much less time with the two sides hanging out before the inevitable tragedy strikes. Great young cast of guys that would go on to have solid careers.

movies.title: A Taxi Driver
movies.reviewText: A remarkable film even more relevant now than when it was released. It feels like we‚Äôre not far in America from what was happening in South Korea in 1980. The third act is thrilling and moving, seeing all the people who sacrificed to get the true story of what was happening out to the world. Song Kang-ho is terrific as always.

movies.title: The Jacket
movies.reviewText: Hadn‚Äôt seen this in forever but it still holds up as a great genre movie whose genre isn‚Äôt immediately apparent. The setup is pretty economical and the cast is solid (including a pre-Bond Daniel Craig) for what‚Äôs basically a B-movie. The central relationship is a bit weird/creepy but Brody and Knightley do a decent job of selling it anyway.

movies.title: Zootopia 2
movies.reviewText: All cops are bastards ‚Äî especially those fucking zebras. I couldn‚Äôt tell you anything about Zootopia 1, which I saw in the theater with my stepson, who is about to turn 22. My boys, who are 3 and almost 7, weren‚Äôt even born when the first one came out and hadn‚Äôt seen it at all. But that didn‚Äôt stop them from enjoying the sequel. We had a good time and I appreciated the numerous references to other movies that went right over my boys‚Äô heads. Some inspired voice acting (David Strathairn left no crumbs) and a nice message, despite all the furry copaganda.

movies.title: Joint Security Area
movies.reviewText: Wasn‚Äôt really into the framing device of the investigation and all the time jumps, but watching these guys raised to believe they were enemies hanging out was sublime. Knowing that tragedy was just around the corner made it bittersweet. Lee Byung-hun and Song Kang-ho are so great.

movies.title: Jaws
movies.reviewText: As I was watching this for the first time in forever I realized I had only ever seen the edited for network TV version as a kid. I imagined how wild it would have been to see this when it came out, in a giant movie house, of which if there are any left have been chopped up into much smaller screening rooms. It‚Äôs kind of a small miracle this movie got made at all. It still holds up 50 years later. Robert Shaw is especially great. Love Spielberg‚Äôs ambition, which he‚Äôs used to crank out banger after banger consistently over five decades.

movies.title: The Secret Agent
movies.reviewText: I found this to be a bit inscrutable, but loved the 70s aesthetic and Wagner Moura‚Äôs performance. Things started getting interesting near the end but then it kind of drops the ball. RIP Udo Kier, who has a brief but memorable scene.

movies.title: The Friends of Eddie Coyle
movies.reviewText: I found this to be pretty tedious, focusing on the lowest of low-level crooks. Mitchum and Boyle are great but this was a rough movie with an extremely unsatisfying ending.

movies.title: Cocktail
movies.reviewText: I‚Äôve got a soft spot for this corny-ass movie. The years I spent bartending were the hardest I ever worked in my life but also some of the most fun, and I had nothing on Cruise‚Äôs Brian Flanagan. Back to back nights with a Bryan Brown movie. Shame that guy didn‚Äôt become a bigger star.

movies.title: Left-Handed Girl
movies.reviewText: Heard great things about this and only learned from the opening credits that Sean Baker worked on this with his long-time collaborator, director Shih-Ching Tsou. The production feels similar in style to Baker‚Äôs films, colorful, vibrant and intimate (and shot on an iPhone), but with the unique perspective of Tsou. This film is delightful. The little girl is adorable and steals every scene she‚Äôs in. But the generational dynamic between the mother and her older daughter, as well as the grandmother is really complex and compelling. I hope more people see this!

movies.title: F/X
movies.reviewText: Loved this movie as a kid and happy to learn that it still holds up pretty well! Clever use of practical effects. Great supporting cast, including Brian Dennehy and Gordon from Sesame Street!

movies.title: Ms .45
movies.reviewText: A really deranged super hero origin story. The world needs more Ms 45s right now.

movies.title: The Net
movies.reviewText: First time watching since it came out and wow, this feels like it was written by a guy whose only experience with computers was AOL. All of the dudes in this are so gross. Bless Sandra Bullock who‚Äôs trying her damndest with just a terrible script. Apparently Carl Reiner LOVED this movie.

movies.title: Heist
movies.reviewText: Hadn‚Äôt seen this since the theater and remembered next to nothing about it but thoroughly enjoyed it this go around. Hackman is great here, still banging out hits at 71. Loved Delroy Lindo and Ricky Jay as his trusty crew. Rockwell is such a slime ball here, it‚Äôs almost like he‚Äôs in another movie.

movies.title: Marty Supreme
movies.reviewText: Loved every minute of this. Safdie bringing that manic Uncut Gems/Good Time energy. Timoth√©e just having a great time. A lot more excitement (and gunplay) than I expected from a movie about table tennis. Loved the anachronistic soundtrack. Loved the eclectic supporting cast. (George Gervin? Abel Ferrara? Fran Drescher?) A great time at the movies.

movies.title: Outland
movies.reviewText: Pretty standard cop movie set in space for no apparent reason, other than to capitalize on the popularity of sci-fi movies of the time and maybe to kill people off in the most horrific ways possible. Connery looks bored here, surrounded by a bunch of familiar character actors like Young Frankenstein‚Äôs monster, Doogie Howser‚Äôs dad, Noah Wylie‚Äôs mom from ER and Lester Freemon from The Wire. Entertaining enough though.

movies.title: The Apartment
movies.reviewText: An all-time helluva script with great performances by Lemon and particularly MacLaine. Seems pretty edgy for the time, though I‚Äôm often surprised watching old movies that deal with pretty serious issues without a lot of innuendo. A great new years movie, if not the best.

movies.title: Electric Dreams
movies.reviewText: Extremely 80s but despite the archaic technology it feels very relevant to the current age of LLMs and generative AI. Virginia Madsen is just radiant here. Easy to see why everyone in the movie, including the computer, are immediately smitten with her. Ah, to be young and in love in San Francisco.

movies.title: Kumail Nanjiani: Night Thoughts
movies.reviewText: Better than Eternals.

movies.title: Trading Places
movies.reviewText: Still a classic. Can‚Äôt believe Eddie was only 22 here. The whole premise is wildly implausible but that‚Äôs part of its charm. Love the callback to Randolph and Mortimer in Coming to America.

movies.title: Nobody's Fool
movies.reviewText: Newman really elevates this whole picture with his effortless charm. Not sure it works nearly as well without him. Loved PSH here in a minor but very PSH role.

movies.title: Jarhead
movies.reviewText: This movie always resonated with me because I spent most of high school terrified that I was going to get drafted to fight in the first Gulf War. Really like the cast and Deakins‚Äô gorgeous cinematography. Not a lot happens but that‚Äôs kind of the point.

movies.title: Die Hard With a Vengeance
movies.reviewText: Starts strong, love the chemistry between Willis and Jackson. A little overstuffed with the bomb plot and the heist plot. Seems to just keep going and going. Still a fun ride and one of the most New York crime capers since Taking of Pelham One Two Three. The last Die Hard movie, as far as I‚Äôm concerned.

movies.title: Innerspace
movies.reviewText: Still a delight all these years later, thanks to Martin Short‚Äôs physical comedy and a fun mix of practical and special effects. Totally forgot Meg Ryan was in this. And Robert Picardo as Cowboy!

movies.title: The Last Boy Scout
movies.reviewText: I remember digging this when it came out, when both Willis and Wayans were at the peak of their fame. On paper, a Tony Scott movie written by Shane Black with this cast seems like a sure-fire hit. But this is not a particularly good movie. The dialogue has aged poorly (if it was ever good to begin with) and almost everyone involved just seems bored. That the villain‚Äôs goal is to legalize sports gambling at any cost is pretty laughable today.

movies.title: Sorry, Baby
movies.reviewText: Impressive debut from writer/director and star Eva Victor. Some truly sublime moments but ultimately I found it to be a little slow. Loved seeing Lucas Hedges and John Carroll Lynch pop up in this.

movies.title: When Harry Met Sally...
movies.reviewText: Hadn‚Äôt seen this probably since high school but as an adult this movie is a banger. Incredible writing and great performances by Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan. This thing is so tight it just whizzes by.

movies.title: The Running Man
movies.reviewText: Not that the original is a masterpiece but this remake adds very little to the premise except an extra half hour of runtime. The original feels prescient in it's depiction of reality TV, deepfakes and authoritarian dystopia. This just feels like a fun house mirror of our current reality.

movies.title: The Shrouds
movies.reviewText: Frustratingly bad. The script is so clunky that even this cast struggled to sell it.

movies.title: Eternity
movies.reviewText: Omg, just go to Polyamory World and be done with it.

movies.title: It's a Wonderful Life
movies.reviewText: Get me, I'm giving out stars!

movies.title: The Holdovers
movies.reviewText: Could see this being an annual holidays watch. It‚Äôs so good. Really enjoyed hanging out with these characters again.

movies.title: Minority Report
movies.reviewText: Watching this for the first time on 4K Blu-Ray and it didn‚Äôt add much since the movie is kind of purposefully grungy to begin with. The effects, pretty impressive at the time, don‚Äôt hold up great and the stunts seem tame by modern Cruise standards. Still, this remains a great sci-fi movie with Spielberg‚Äôs signature flair. It feels like a straight noir movie with a futuristic sheen. Its only mistake is that it presupposes that the people operating our dystopian, techno-fascist police state would be remotely competent.

movies.title: Die My Love
movies.reviewText: Not my first Lynne Ramsey movie. I‚Äôm used to being uncomfortable. There was so much here I found unbearable. Never has a movie made me wish harm on a dog. I spent the whole movie worried about the baby. I understand the need to shoot day for night but it was so frequent in this. This felt like Night Bitch for intellectuals. Great cast but several of them are seriously wasted here. I enjoyed this about as much as Jennifer Lawrence and Robert Pattinson seemed to enjoy promoting it, which is to say hardly at all.

movies.title: The Driver
movies.reviewText: A serviceable dad movie, light on plot/dialogue with some fun, if drawn-out, car chases.

movies.title: The Lives of Others
movies.reviewText: Wow, that was great. Felt very relevant to everything going on in the US right now. This is ultimately the degree of control (or lack thereof) we can expect if things continue to spiral here. The last 15 minutes sealed this as an all-timer.

movies.title: Eephus
movies.reviewText: Charming existential baseball movie. If you don‚Äôt care about baseball you might find it to be a bit of a slog. It‚Äôs just about the lowest stakes game imaginable with a bunch of locals of all ages playing for the love of it, if nothing else.

movies.title: Sinners
movies.reviewText: Still have the same issues with this the second time around but what a cool fucking movie.

movies.title: Breakdown: 1975
movies.reviewText: Piqued my interest because I was born in ‚Äò75. Spends seemingly more time talking about the events of the 70s that led to the movies than the movies themselves. Throws in movies from 74 and 76 to have more to work with. It was mildly interesting but I would have rather learned more about the movies than the historical context and political climate around them.

movies.title: The Mastermind
movies.reviewText: Oh, I get it. ‚ÄúMastermind‚Äù is ironic.

movies.title: Stand by Me
movies.reviewText: Revisiting some Rob Reiner movies and realized I hadn‚Äôt seen this since River Phoenix died. It made this watch all the more tragic. A great coming of age movie with such great casting for the four boys. Hard to imagine anyone else playing those roles. And evil Keifer!

movies.title: Boogie Nights
movies.reviewText: It‚Äôd been a long time since I last saw this so I was thrilled when the 4k Blu-Ray arrived today. This movie still fucking slaps. An incredible ensemble all working at the top of their game. (Wahlberg might have peaked here.) This was the first PT Anderson movie I saw and I must have watched it a dozen times. Simply a masterpiece. The long takes, the match cuts, the soundtrack! Hits a lot different now that I have kids and am closer to Burt Reynolds‚Äôs age than anyone.

movies.title: Wake Up Dead Man
movies.reviewText: Another fun mystery with a deep cast. Josh O‚ÄôConnor and Glenn Close really shine. I‚Äôve seen all the Knives Out films exactly one time and, while I enjoyed them, would be hard-pressed to tell you a single detail about them. Part of that is Blanc is not a particularly interesting character. Aside from being good at solving mysteries he doesn‚Äôt seem to have any other apparent skills or interests and instead seems to just serve as a way to provide exposition to the mystery. ¬†This one has several memorable scenes and felt like the most personal of the three. Time will tell if this one remains memorable.

movies.title: Getting LOST
movies.reviewText: A little up its own ass about the importance of Lost, which was a show I loved. It truly was a groundbreaking show and at the same time kind of the end of an era of appointment viewing and communal TV watching experiences. To its credit, the doc doesn‚Äôt shy away from the notorious finale or reports that the writer‚Äôs room was highly toxic, and the showrunners own up to it. Great seeing a lot of the cast and hearing from fans and early podcasters about how the show changed their lives. Definitely got a little nostalgic and it gave me the itch to revisit the show.

movies.title: Irreversible
movies.reviewText: That the guy in Sentimental Value gave a DVD of this to his nine-year-old grandson is killing me now. This is maybe one of the most disturbing movies I‚Äôve ever seen. Appreciated the series of long takes and incredibly vulnerable performance by Monica Bellucci. If you go to a place called The Rectum, you shouldn‚Äôt be surprised by anything that happens there.

movies.title: Sentimental Value
movies.reviewText: I was hyped for this after Worst Person in the World but this one didn‚Äôt really resonate with me. Renate Reinsve is great once again. Weird to see Elle Fanning with legs after Predator Badlands.¬†It felt like the movie within the movie might have been more interesting. Adding The Piano Teacher and Irreversible to my watchlist.

movies.title: SirƒÅt
movies.reviewText: The Mad Max of rave movies. This movie lost me at a certain point but I stuck with it anyway and it only got more stressful from there. Fucking hell.

movies.title: It Was Just an Accident
movies.reviewText: Thought this was fine but the Blair Witch-ass ending elevated it. Looking forward to the American remake with an ICE agent in a few years.

movies.title: Star Wars
movies.reviewText: You knew the kid was special when he raw-dogged the trench run with no targeting computer.¬†Finally got all the way through this with my boys (6 and 3) on the third attempt and, as much as I loved it as a kid, it‚Äôs really just like three good scenes held together with great sound and a whole lot of nostalgia. From my kids‚Äô perspective, the opening is great, and then it‚Äôs just people talking in the desert for like 30 minutes until anything remotely interesting happens. There‚Äôs some fun stuff on the Death Star and then the final assault, which this was the first time my kids made it that far. In the end they thought it was bullshit that Luke and Han got medals and they just left Chewbacca standing there like a goon.My oldest was shocked to learn they made more than one Star Wars movie.

movies.title: Never Let Me Go
movies.reviewText: Looking back at my original review I was quite surprised I still feel the same. I don‚Äôt remember the nature of the characters‚Äô purpose being as clearly telegraphed from the beginning, so while the ending is still a gut punch, it didn‚Äôt feel as revelatory. Being 15 years older though, the ending hit different.

movies.title: Jay Kelly
movies.reviewText: I‚Äôm a big Clooney fan but this felt so self-indulgent. Beautifully shot, great cast. Has its moments but ultimately I just didn‚Äôt care much about Kelly and all his regrets.

movies.title: Nuremberg
movies.reviewText: Ostensibly a courtroom drama with very little courtroom and not much drama. Half of the dialogue sounds like a Wikipedia entry being read to other characters to provide context and exposition. The whole affair feels like a thinly-veiled warning that OMG THIS COULD HAPPEN AGAIN, which might be prescient if it weren‚Äôt already happening. I‚Äôll tell you what though, looking forward to Nuremberg 2!

movies.title: The International
movies.reviewText: Pretty dull, by-the-numbers conspiracy thriller with paper thin characters. You can tell they spent a lot of money on gorgeous locations around the world (including an actually decent shootout set piece at the Guggenheim) but none of it adds up to much.

movies.title: Tango & Cash
movies.reviewText: If you asked ChatGPT to write a script for an 80s buddy cop action movie, you‚Äôd get Tango & Cash. Chock full of tropes and 80s character actors (and young Teri Hatcher!) I vaguely remember this being fun when it came out, and it still has its moments, but it‚Äôs pretty cringe by today‚Äôs standards.

movies.title: Lurker
movies.reviewText: What if Nightcrawler but boring and annoying? I found just about every character in this deeply unpleasant. They had a chance to bring me around at the end but decided to double down instead. Ugh.

movies.title: Casino
movies.reviewText: Not quite on the same level as Goodfellas but looks great in 4k. Pesci is excellent and Sharon Stone is delightfully unhinged.

movies.title: Rental Family
movies.reviewText: ‚ÄúSometimes all we need is for someone to look us in the eye to remind us we exist.‚Äù Well, shit. This movie absolutely destroyed me. Brendan Fraser is great but the entire ensemble is just so endearing. Definitely keep some tissues handy for this one.

movies.title: Eyes Wide Shut
movies.reviewText: This movie hits different as a married man. Not at all what I remembered it to be when it first came out. This felt like Fincher‚Äôs The Game but with a lot more naked women. If there‚Äôs a lesson here it‚Äôs that you don‚Äôt take a taxi to an orgy.

movies.title: Police Story
movies.reviewText: The sheer amount of broken glass in this movie is impressive. A pretty solid sampling of Jackie‚Äôs signature blend of action and comedy with some dangerously over-the-top stunt work. The plot is pretty thin and there‚Äôs lots of Three‚Äôs Company-style innuendo misunderstandings in between the action beats. I have no doubt Jackie was a John Ritter fan and/or vice versa. When this is clicking it‚Äôs an absolute joy.

movies.title: Texasville
movies.reviewText: Is this the original lega-sequel? This takes place 33 years after The Last Picture Show and gets nearly the whole cast back together, for better or worse. Tonally it takes a sharp turn into slapstick and feels like a made-for-TV movie. They pretty much sideline Sonny, who was the heart of the original, in favor of setting up a will-they-or-won‚Äôt-they reunion between Jeff Bridges and Cybill Shepherd. Still, it‚Äôs fun revisiting these characters later in life. The town is still horny as ever.

movies.title: The Last Picture Show
movies.reviewText: This feels so ahead of its time. It should've been called The Horniest Little Town in Texas or something. Lots of great characters in this really just longing for companionship in the middle of nowhere. Young Jeff Bridges and Cybill Shepherd! Though Timothy Bottoms kind of steals the show. Great movie.

movies.title: Blue Moon
movies.reviewText: "No one ever loved me that much." Ethan Hawke is doing some of his best work here as Lorenz Hart, in full Dorf on Golf mode. His character is simultaneously amusing, endearing and exhausting. Margaret Qualley is radiant, as usual, as the young object of Hart's unrequited affection. I only wish she was in more scenes.

movies.title: Planes, Trains and Automobiles
movies.reviewText: Realizing I stayed in Chicago almost my entire life to avoid this exact situation.

movies.title: Are We Good?
movies.reviewText: If you're not a Maron-head you might not love this doc, which is largely about Marc dealing with the grief of losing his partner, director Lynn Shelton. This is not a comprehensive biography by any means. Maron has a vulnerability unlike any comic and I think that's why he feels so relatable. Here he's extremely honest about his feelings and working through them through his stand-up.

movies.title: GoodFellas
movies.reviewText: First time seeing this since marrying an Italian woman and now everything makes sense.

movies.title: The Roses
movies.reviewText: Was this written by AI? It's ostensibly a comedy, with a cast of people who are usually funny. If I lost three of my fingers in a horrible accident I'd still be able to count how many times I chuckled watching this movie on one hand. Deeply unfunny.

movies.title: After the Hunt
movies.reviewText: I generally enjoy Luca's work but this was a miss for me. Everyone in this is painfully unsympathetic. Julia Roberts is particularly good at it ‚Äî Oscar-worthy, even. Not sure what I was supposed to take away from this as I didn't go to Yale. This film asks and answers the question: what if Wonder Boys was not funny and painfully long?

movies.title: The Andromeda Strain
movies.reviewText: Some cool vibes but this felt like the first 10 minutes of a science fiction movie drawn out to a full-length movie. If you're into amino acids and alkalis and shit you'll probably love this movie.

movies.title: No Other Choice
movies.reviewText: A lot wackier than Decision to Leave but takes that film's incredible cinematography and editing up a notch. Lee Byung-hun is surprisingly adept at comedy. I had fun but it felt like it was trying to cram in a few too many ideas.

movies.title: Train Dreams
movies.reviewText: Holy shit, this movie wrecked me. Gorgeously shot, reminded me of a Terrence Malick film. Joel Edgerton gives such a restrained performance. You can't take your eyes off him when he's on screen. I'll be thinking of this movie for a long time.

movies.title: If I Had Legs I'd Kick You
movies.reviewText: A deeply unsettling watch. Felt almost Lynchian at some points. A tremendous performance by Rose Byrne. Hard to say much about this without spoiling it, but things I questioned for most of the movie eventually paid off. There's a lot to unpack here that almost demands repeat viewings. Not sure I can handle it though! I have to go hug my wife now.

movies.title: The Hustler
movies.reviewText: Wow, that was a lot darker than I was expecting after watching Color of Money. Newman is great here once again as Fast Eddie Felson. LOVED Jackie Gleason as Minnesota Fats. The Honeymooners was one of my favorite shows as a kid and Gleason does so much here with so little dialogue. George C. Scott plays probably one of the scummiest characters I‚Äôve ever seen him play and does it well. Piper Laurie was probably my favorite of all. Her character Sarah is truly complicated and tragic. Interesting contrast of style between this almost noir style film and Scorsese‚Äôs colorful and kinetic Color of Money. They both work!

movies.title: The Color of Money
movies.reviewText: Paul Newman is perfect in this. Feels as though just as his character is taking Vincent under his wing as an up-and-coming pool shark, Newman is also taking Cruise under his wing as an actor. Cruise‚Äôs young, cocky charm is right at home here. For a brief moment I imagined this as a prequel to Collateral. Love Scorsese‚Äôs direction and, as usual, the soundtrack rips. Also fun seeing some recognizable Chicago spots in the beginning.

movies.title: Being Eddie
movies.reviewText: ‚ÄúSurviving being Eddie Murphy is a hell of an accomplishment,‚Äù Dave Chappelle says to close this doc. Indeed, it‚Äôs a small miracle that Murphy, one of my comedy idols, has done just about everything in showbiz and come out unscathed, unlike so many of his contemporaries. Sure, this doc doesn‚Äôt offer a ton of insight into the man, but it‚Äôs a celebration of a body of work of over 40 years that has brought us so much joy and influenced countless others to follow in his footsteps. There‚Äôs nothing particularly illuminating here but Murphy does offer some nuggets of wisdom, hard won after surviving this long as one of the most famous people on Earth. Just seeing that smile and hearing that laugh is a joy. And it‚Äôs clear Murphy is far from finished.

movies.title: The Parallax View
movies.reviewText: Pretty unsatisfying conspiracy thriller. Lots of long, drawn out sequences that are supposed to build suspense but they all lead to a pretty lame outcome. Beatty is pretty good though.

movies.title: Klute
movies.reviewText: What an odd, horny, 70s noir. Jane Fonda is great in a really meaty role. Donald Sutherland, on the other hand, is surprisingly one-note. Some great shots and lighting. The mystery isn‚Äôt all that compelling but Fonda‚Äôs performance certainly is.

movies.title: Cloud
movies.reviewText: Maybe I just don‚Äôt understand how reselling (and assistants) work in Japan but I couldn‚Äôt help think, ‚Äúwhy go through all the trouble?‚Äù The last act makes up for the dull setup but the whole thing seems like a drastic overreaction.

movies.title: One Battle After Another
movies.reviewText: Ahhhhh this movie is just so perfectly timed for our current moment. Having been subjected to weeks of ICE and Border Patrol running amok here in Chicago, the opening scene feels so cathartic. From there it‚Äôs just a relentless ride with so much manic energy, save Benicio‚Äôs Sensei Sergio, who exudes cool calm when the movie reaches its most tense moments. On second viewing I totally get the criticism that this story of mostly women of color revolutionaries is centered largely around a couple of white guys. I wish we got more of Teyana Taylor and Regina Hall, who gets barely any screen time. But damn, what a ride.

movies.title: Frankenstein
movies.reviewText: In an interview, Del Toro said that his entire filmography is basically Frankenstein. His passion for the story is on full display here. Just an incredible achievement.

movies.title: Bugonia
movies.reviewText: Delightfully unhinged, as you‚Äôd expect from Yorgos Lanthimos, but this felt more accessible than any of his prior films, including The Favourite. Took me awhile to get on board with it as it feels like so much time is spent setting up Jesse Plemons‚Äô conspiracy theory before things really start getting interesting. Emma Stone is doing some of her best work here. This will probably grow on me with repeat viewings.

movies.title: Roofman
movies.reviewText: Surprisingly charming and light coming from the director of Blue Valentine and The Place Beyond the Pines. A lot of it is thanks to Channing Tatum, but the cast is also deep with notable character actors. Based on a true story, it‚Äôs pretty apparent early on that things are not going to work out and it‚Äôs just a matter of how and when.

movies.title: Kundun
movies.reviewText: A gorgeous looking movie that feels quite authentic with its largely Tibetan cast. Hard not to compare this with Seven Years in Tibet, which is maybe less authentic but has more focus. This felt kind of aimless, hitting the main beats of the Dalai Lama‚Äôs life but left me unfulfilled. I‚Äôm fascinated by rituals and traditions and this film offers a lot in that regard.

movies.title: Splitsville
movies.reviewText: Surprisingly fun and unexpectedly has one of the best fight scenes of the year. Made me consider opening my marriage if for no other reason than to expand my circle of guy friends. Movie night? Free chiropractic adjustments? What‚Äôs not to like?

movies.title: The Smashing Machine
movies.reviewText: Not so much a transformation The Rock undergoes here as Mark Kerr, aside from just enough prosthetics to make him not look like THE ROCK. Props to him though for letting go of his typical brand of hero and showing some vulnerability here. The fight scenes are the least interesting thing about this movie and there are a lot of them. I hope despite the poor box office this movie pulled in, Johnson is motivated to continue to push his limits as an actor. This movie shows it‚Äôs possible.

movies.title: Black Phone 2
movies.reviewText: Watching this I couldn‚Äôt recall hardly anything about the first movie. It didn‚Äôt seem to matter much. This sequel takes Ethan Hawke‚Äôs Grabber (the dumbest horror villain name ever?) into the realm of Nightmare on Elm Street with some pretty cool scenes. None of it really makes any sense if you stop and think about it, but in the moment it‚Äôs fun. I‚Äôll likely forget all about this one by the time the inevitable Black Phone 3 comes out.

movies.title: Good Fortune
movies.reviewText: This is It‚Äôs a Wonderful Life for the post-capitalism age, except its characters (except Keke Palmer‚Äôs) seemingly have never done anything for anyone but themselves their whole lives. The movie‚Äôs only (heavy-handed) message seems to be ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt it suck being poor?‚Äù Still, enjoyed hanging with Keanu‚Äôs fallen angel, living his best life eating tacos and dancing.

movies.title: Predator: Badlands
movies.reviewText: Gotta hand it to Dan Trachtenberg, who continues to expand on the Predator universe in new and interesting ways. This sprinkles in some Alien and even some Mandalorian. Unfortunately, like that show, this is just wall-to-wall CG that looks like very little of it was shot in a real location, even though the end credits swear it was shot in New Zealand and Australia. This may have been better served as an animated film like Killer of Killers. Still, some really inventive Predator tech and improvised weapons on display.

movies.title: Mean Streets
movies.reviewText: This probably felt more groundbreaking at the time and you can see a lot of the seeds of Scorsese‚Äôs later filmography here, but it was kind of tedious to get through. These characters are not particularly fun to hang out with and that‚Äôs what most of the movie is.

movies.title: TRON: Ares
movies.reviewText: Killer soundtrack. Some interesting concepts but executed in the dullest way possible. Every single person in the cast made me think ‚Äúwhy is this person in this?‚Äù

movies.title: After Hours
movies.reviewText: Feels like a movie that could only happen in the 80s. I had a lot of fun with this. So different from Scorsese‚Äôs usual material but his style adds so much. Very surreal and filled with odd characters. Felt like an ancestor of I Think You Should Leave.

movies.title: Mr. Scorsese
movies.reviewText: Came away from this with a greater understanding of Scorsese‚Äôs filmography and the man himself. Doesn‚Äôt shy away from some of the darker parts of his personality that are actually critical to his work. It was fascinating to see Marty‚Äôs contemporaries like De Palma and Spielberg, prolific directors in their own right, heaping praise and admiration on him, not to mention those whose work he influenced. My only quibble is that five episodes is somehow too short, glossing over his recent career and collaboration with Leonardo DiCaprio. Now I have to check out a half dozen Scorsese movies I haven‚Äôt seen and revisit another half dozen.

movies.title: Ballad of a Small Player
movies.reviewText: Wow, people hated this! I loved it. This movie is dripping with color and Colin Farrell‚Äôs flop sweat. It has the manic energy of Uncut Gems with an unexpected twist that sets it apart from the typical degenerate gambler movie.

movies.title: Frankenstein
movies.reviewText: Far from my favorite adaptation but man, the iconography in this film has endured for almost 100 years. The mad scientist‚Äôs lab, the angry mob, and the creature design have been repeated so many times in pop culture. What the hell was with that last scene though? lol

movies.title: National Theatre Live: Frankenstein
movies.reviewText: An interesting stage adaptation. Johnny Lee Miller is great as The Creature. I was under the impression he would switch roles with Benedict Cumberbatch‚Äôs Frankenstein midway through but the version I watched they played the same character all the way through. Really clever set design. It was remarkable what they were able to do in such a relatively small space.

movies.title: Frankenstein
movies.reviewText: Hooked me from the start and never let go. I don‚Äôt have any great affinity for the source material or subsequent adaptations, but this is just so perfectly in Del Toro‚Äôs wheelhouse and he executes it wonderfully. Incredible production design and costumes, as you‚Äôd expect. Jacob Elordi surprised me. I didn‚Äôt think much of him in his previous work but he‚Äôs great here, really giving the creature humanity. Definitely deserves seeing on a big screen, if you can.

movies.title: Good Boy
movies.reviewText: A great premise and a very good boy but it really didn‚Äôt click with me. That poor dog actor is going to need therapy after what they put him through.

movies.title: A House of Dynamite
movies.reviewText: Great direction, deep ensemble cast, gripping first act. But subsequent acts diffuse an otherwise tense setup and the ending is extremely unsatisfying. That said, the most chilling thing about this film is the idea that this could happen in real life, only the people in charge are a bunch of incompetent, sociopathic grifters who wouldn‚Äôt bat an eye at letting an American city be annihilated if it suited them.

movies.title: Stiller & Meara: Nothing Is Lost
movies.reviewText: This doc is ostensibly about Ben Stiller‚Äôs parents, the comedy duo, Stiller and Meara. But it‚Äôs just as much about Ben reckoning with his relationship with his showbiz parents and how his own success affected his children in a similar way. It‚Äôs an intimate and honest portrait of marriage and parenthood that took me by surprise. There‚Äôs definitely no way I could work with my wife without us killing each other.

movies.title: The Long Walk
movies.reviewText: I found this to be really engaging and moving. Great world building on what I assume was a pretty small budget. The contestants were pretty well fleshed out considering only a few get most of the screen time. You feel for each one that gets left behind. I really liked Cooper Hoffman and David Jonson in this. I can imagine looking back on this in 20 years and marveling at the early roles of a couple of great actors. Also rivals Drive My Car for the latest title card. I laughed when it came up. I absolutely would have been the first person to die.

movies.title: House
movies.reviewText: This movie is doing a lot. Just a ton of uh, interesting, stylistic choices. If you go with the flow, it‚Äôs a fun and often funny haunted house tale.

movies.title: A Nightmare on Elm Street
movies.reviewText: Haven‚Äôt seen this in DECADES, so it was fun to revisit. Nightmare definitely had the best premise of all the 80s slasher franchises, not to mention the best villain. Just the iconography of Freddy is so good. But man, in hindsight this is pretty rough. It plays fast and loose with its rules and the last 20 minutes is like Inception meets Home Alone. Still, there‚Äôs some great practical effects and laugh out loud moments. A great nostalgia trip.

movies.title: Downey Wrote That
movies.reviewText: So glad Downey is having a year. He was in One Battle After Another, has a part in the new Tim Robinson series, The Paper Company, and now this documentary giving Jim his due as one of the most prolific comedy writers of the last 50 years. Glad to finally watch a doc that gives someone their flowers while they‚Äôre still with us. I only wish it was longer. You could easily do a Last Dance¬†length documentary with all the material Downey has written.

movies.title: Downey Wrote That
movies.reviewText: So glad Downey is having a year. He was in One Battle After Another, has a part in the new Tim Robinson series, The Paper Company, and now this documentary giving Jim his due as one of the most prolific comedy writers of the last 50 years. Glad to finally watch a doc that gives someone their flowers while they‚Äôre still with us. I only wish it was longer. You could easily do a Last Dance¬†length documentary with all the material Downey has written.

movies.title: Pulse
movies.reviewText: Some chillingly weird visuals but this was a disappointing follow-up to Cure for me. None of the characters were particularly well-developed and there wasn‚Äôt so much of a plot as just weird shit happening.

movies.title: A Big Bold Beautiful Journey
movies.reviewText: Wow, people really did not like this movie. I completely get it. But for whatever reason this spoke to me like some of my favorite films like Eternal Sunshine and Once. This doesn‚Äôt come close to the highs of those films but I dug the cast, Kogonada‚Äôs direction, and just found a lot to relate to. But also, the Joker is going to really hate this.

movies.title: The Keep
movies.reviewText: I had no idea Michael Mann made a horror movie. It feels like a riff on Carpenter, with the Tangerine Dream synth soundtrack and wild effects. It‚Äôs definitely a vibe, with some interesting actors including youngish Ian MacKellan and horny Scott Glenn. It didn‚Äôt add up to much but at least it doesn‚Äôt overstay its welcome.

movies.title: Cure
movies.reviewText: Holy shit. This movie takes its time setting up the central mystery, teasing a little more with each murder. When you finally start to piece it together, it's absolutely riveting. Halfway through I thought, where have I seen this detective before? Turns out it's my boy Hirayama from Perfect Days. I imagine it now as a sequel ‚Äî having experienced the events of this film he quit the force and opted for a simple life cleaning toilets. Anyway, this movie has strong Seven vibes but is doing something completely different. I fucking loved it.

movies.title: Play Dirty
movies.reviewText: For anyone hoping for a worthy follow-up to Kiss Kiss Bang Bang and The Nice Guys, this ain't it. It has its moments but manages to waste a great cast (though happy to see LaKeith Stanfield any time). Feels very much like a 90s movie, down to a woefully miscast Mark Wahlberg as Parker. So many of the action sequences are loaded with bad CG that look right out of a Marvel TV show.

movies.title: John Candy: I Like Me
movies.reviewText: Fucking Johnny Toronto, man. Candy's was one of the first celebrity deaths that really gutted me as a teenager. Every character he played left an indelible mark on my brain. Watching the biggest names in comedy of that era speak effusively about him for two hours, it was almost impossible to get through with dry eyes. What a legend.

movies.title: The Omen
movies.reviewText: Finally got around to seeing this for the first time and found it to be pretty dull. Some fun deaths but the kid is basically a MacGuffin and has no character and barely any dialogue.

movies.title: Caught Stealing
movies.reviewText: Entertaining enough, though it‚Äôs weird to see Aronofsky dip into Guy Ritchie territory. Great ensemble cast. Dug Austin Butler seeming completely out of his league for a change. I was digging this until a particular death halfway through and despite some interesting twists it never fully won me back.

movies.title: Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy
movies.reviewText: This is a well-made and well-acted movie which, even on second viewing, completely confounds me. I found the whole thing to be pretty inscrutable, even with subtitles on. I had to keep rewinding as I dozed off as white guy after white guy looked pensively into the distance or just said some nonsensical spy shit. I couldn‚Äôt wrap my head around who was who or even why was who? Great seeing Tom Hardy and Benedict Cumberbatch here, who I had no idea about when I first saw this in the theater. And Gary Oldman is immensely watchable, even if I often had no idea what the fuck was going on.

movies.title: Casualties of War
movies.reviewText: Another movie that used to come on cable all the time when I was in high school. I was probably way too young for the subject matter and the movie, particularly the score, still haunts me. A rare dramatic role for Michael J Fox, who was mostly known for comedy at the time. He‚Äôs a little melodramatic but still has that movie star presence, even in such a bleak film. This is my second unhinged Sean Penn as a soldier movie in a row. Great supporting cast of folks who went on to become pretty famous. Especially loved Ving Rhames.

movies.title: One Battle After Another
movies.reviewText: Electric and relentless. A rare PTA film that takes place in current times and it feels so relevant with everything going on in the world. Might be my favorite DiCaprio performance. Sean Penn is so oddly specific in his character choices. Loved Greenwood‚Äôs score and choice needle drops. Glad I saw this in the theater.

movies.title: The Big Heat
movies.reviewText: Surprisingly lurid for a 1950s movie. Glenn Ford is great as a hard-boiled cop going up against a politically connected crime boss. Loved seeing Gloria Grahame (Violet from It‚Äôs a Wonderful Life) as a femme fatale and young Lee Marvin as the head goon. Packs a lot into its 90-minute run time. Only my second Fritz Lang movie and it‚Äôs another banger.

movies.title: M
movies.reviewText: This movie feels so ahead of its time. I'm surprised David Fincher or Bong Joon Ho hasn't remade this, it feels right in their wheelhouse. It meanders a bit but really picks up steam when an unlikely network of citizens catch the trail of the killer, played by Peter Lorre in an incredible performance. The ending is pretty abrupt but gets at the pathology of a serial killer like no film I've ever seen, and Lorre almost makes you sympathize with his character.

movies.title: The Natural
movies.reviewText: Hadn‚Äôt seen this since I was a kid and I‚Äôm not sure I picked up on half the movie. It‚Äôs a little too long and kinda corny, but Redford is so effortlessly cool here. I‚Äôm not sure this movie works with any other actor playing Roy Hobbs. That final play and the score that accompanies it is so iconic it was seared into my memory all these years later even as the rest faded away.

movies.title: The Conspirator
movies.reviewText: I wasn‚Äôt even aware this movie existed until digging into Robert Redford‚Äôs filmography. It‚Äôs a pretty by-the-numbers courtroom drama absolutely stacked with recognizable character actors. The story is chillingly relevant. If the government wants to do something, it‚Äôs not hard for them to stack everything against you. Ostensibly the events depicted here were less likely to happen again once the Supreme Court guaranteed a right to civil trial even in times of war shortly after this trial happened. But if recent events haven‚Äôt made clear, laws don‚Äôt mean shit if the levers of power are held by unscrupulous men.

movies.title: Ordinary People
movies.reviewText: I gotta say I wasn‚Äôt really feeling this for the first half. Having grown up in the northern burbs of Chicago (a gunshot from the border, as I used to say) I couldn‚Äôt care less about the problems of a rich, white family from Lake Forest. But as the characters started to examine themselves and work it out between each other, it became a showcase of great acting, particularly young Timothy Hutton, who has to carry a lot of the dramatic load here. I can see why this was so acclaimed.

movies.title: A River Runs Through It
movies.reviewText: RIP to Robert Redford, who was truly, as the kids say, goated. Filling in some gaps in his filmography with this one, which came out when I was in high school and everything about it looked boring as shit to me, a young idiot. Watching it for the first time now, as a parent of two boys similarly separated in age, I couldn‚Äôt help but wonder which will go on to be a professor, and which I‚Äôll have to bail out of jail. This is a fine movie with great cinematography and earnest performances all around. Brad Pitt, pre superstardom, is particularly mesmerizing. It‚Äôs odd that Redford narrates as the older brother, and not Pitt, who is almost the spitting image of Redford in both looks and charm. Unfortunately the older brother is pretty dull by comparison. The ending really hit hard and made me realize I‚Äôd come to care for these characters, dullness and all. Not sure high school Mike would have felt the same though.

movies.title: The Way of the Gun
movies.reviewText: McQuarrie‚Äôs directorial debut is definitely a product of its time ‚Äî a Y2K crime flick with lots of gun play. If you can get past the edgelord dialogue of the opening minutes, it settles into a pretty solid, modern Western. Love young Benicio Del Toro here as one of a pair of kidnappers who gets in over his head. Not to mention James Fucking Caan as a badass bagman rocking a Member‚Äôs Only jacket. There‚Äôs some great action here and memorable scenes. It‚Äôs incredible McQuarrie went on to direct huge action blockbusters. I‚Äôd love to see him revisit something on a smaller scale like this.

movies.title: Highest 2 Lowest
movies.reviewText: I recently enjoyed Kurosawa‚Äôs High and Low, which is part morality play and part police procedural. Spike Lee‚Äôs remake, on the other hand, replaces the police procedural element with‚Ä¶ a Denzel movie. I love Spike and Denzel, but this remake, like Oldboy, is just completely unnecessary. The score is so overbearing, there‚Äôs almost never a moment when there‚Äôs no music and it doesn‚Äôt fit the vibe of the movie at all. The cops are poorly written and completely inept ‚Äî the movie looks like an ad for the NYPD but then portrays its cops as dipshits, which, ok.Overall it doesn‚Äôt improve on Kurosawa‚Äôs in any way and doesn‚Äôt seem to have much to say by bringing it into the modern era. A huge swing and a miss by Spike.

movies.title: Honey Don't!
movies.reviewText: Love Margaret Qualley but this script doesn‚Äôt do her any favors. There‚Äôs a few fun scenes but the ending just came out of nowhere, rendering most of what happens earlier seemingly meaningless.

movies.title: Aguirre, the Wrath of God
movies.reviewText: I was interested in this because I haven‚Äôt seen many films shot in Peru or about its history. And while the film is largely fictional, it captures a time when the Spanish came to the land of the Incas and pretty much took whatever the fuck they wanted. The Spanish men in this film are largely brutish, greedy, and power hungry, while the native Peruvians seem resigned to their fate more than anything. It‚Äôs a hard movie to reckon with, since I likely wouldn‚Äôt be here otherwise, having both Spanish and native Peruvian ancestry. It‚Äôs pretty fascinating that they were even able to make this, filming chronologically on location in the Amazon. Kinski‚Äôs screen presence is riveting, his face practically chiseled from stone and his eyes bulging.

movies.title: Weapons
movies.reviewText: Right up there with a handful of horror movies that changed the game ‚Äî Blair Witch Project, The Sixth Sense, Get Out. Seeing this gave me that same feeling, like I just watched a magic trick that had never been pulled off before. Definitely glad I saw this in the theater. The crowd experience was amazing. But I‚Äôm so glad to have this available at home and looking forward to making my wife watch it.

movies.title: Possession
movies.reviewText: This movie is completely unhinged with The Room-level acting and writing. Some interesting cinematography and a wild climax but ultimately not a very enjoyable watch.

movies.title: K-19: The Widowmaker
movies.reviewText: Of all the submarine movies, K-19 is one of them. A mix of Crimson Tide and Chernobyl, but never reaches the highs of either of those. Harrison Ford and Liam Neeson are so subdued in this, but maybe that‚Äôs just them emulating Russian culture with their rough Russian accents. When the two meet some 25 years after the events of the film, their makeup makes them look even older than they do in real life, where nearly the same amount of time has passed since this was filmed. You can definitely pick up on some of the themes Bigelow explored in movies like Point Break and The Hurt Locker, but overall this is a pretty forgettable exercise.

movies.title: Duplicity
movies.reviewText: Tony Gilroy‚Äôs follow-up to Michael Clayton is a fun romp but feels like watered-down Soderbergh. As much as I love Clive Owen, I couldn‚Äôt help think while watching this that Clooney was Gilroy‚Äôs first choice to play opposite Julia Roberts but was otherwise busy. The premise is great and anytime Paul Giamatti or Tom Wilkinson are on screen they cooked. Didn‚Äôt love the ending but it did subvert my expectations.

movies.title: We're No Angels
movies.reviewText: Around the time this came out on cable I used to watch it all the time. It‚Äôs a goofy premise (which I only now learned was written by David Mamet, of all people) but DeNiro and Penn really sell it. DeNiro with his entire range of facial expressions and Penn with his earnestness. There‚Äôs also a spunky young Demi Moore, John C Reilly doing his thing, and Wallace Shawn. It‚Äôs almost cartoonishly silly, but it still tickled me all these years later.

movies.title: Unknown Number: The High School Catfish
movies.reviewText: I hated every minute of this. It‚Äôs supposed to be a huge shock who the culprit is but it felt pretty obvious they wouldn‚Äôt make a documentary about it if it were anyone else. I felt bad for the kids involved and this makes me want to never get my kids a phone. Thanks for nothing to Dave who suggested we watch this.

movies.title: Malice
movies.reviewText: I remember seeing this on opening night in a sold out theater, an impressionable 18-year-old, barely a month into my freshman year in college. I had never seen anything like it. Years later it‚Äôs obvious the movies that influenced it, but to mention them here would spoil the surprises. Suffice it to say, this movie still slaps. I love it unapologetically. The central cast is great, including an all-time monologue from Alec Baldwin about his ‚Äúgod complex.‚Äù Lots of great supporting actors pop up, including Anne Bancroft and a 21-year-old Gwenyth Paltrow. Also, I was shocked to learn it was co-written by Aaron Sorkin! When the final twist was revealed, I cackled out loud and it brought me back to that packed college theater where everyone was hooting and hollering.

movies.title: Naked Gun 33‚Öì: The Final Insult
movies.reviewText: Certainly the horniest Naked Gun, if not the funniest. The opening spoof of the train station scene in The Untouchables¬†is funnier than anything in Naked Gun 2. Lots of funny bits around Frank and Jane‚Äôs relationship. Fred Ward is having a blast hamming it up as the villain. As with the rest of the series, some of the jokes didn‚Äôt age well, but this one had me laughing out loud quite a bit.

movies.title: See No Evil, Hear No Evil
movies.reviewText: A cable staple when I was a teenager. Loved the chemistry between Wilder and Pryor. No one else could probably pull off this premise. Joan Severance was also formative to young Mike. üòÖ Happy to say this movie still tickles me, even if some of the humor hasn‚Äôt aged well. This is like watching Magic and Larry Bird in their prime. But also, Kevin Spacey is in this?

movies.title: Crimson Tide
movies.reviewText: Still holds up as one of the great submarine movies. Solid cast led by Denzel and Hackman, both doing their best work here, backed by a bunch of great character actors. Zimmer‚Äôs score is excellent, and Tony Scott‚Äôs flair for shooting action and tension is top notch. Even the lighting is awesome. This could have been released in 2025 and it would still be a banger.

movies.title: The Naked Gun 2¬Ω: The Smell of Fear
movies.reviewText: Even at 85 minutes this sequel is a slog to get through. I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôd seen this several times but almost none of it felt familiar. In fact, minutes after the credits rolled I‚Äôve already forgotten most of it.

movies.title: Eenie Meanie
movies.reviewText: Great premise, some fun car chases, loved the Elmore Leonard-ness of the script but I just couldn‚Äôt buy the central relationship. I don‚Äôt know if the guy was just miscast or was poorly written but yikes. Samara Weaving is great and it‚Äôs always nice when Andy Garcia and Marshawn Lynch pop up. The way things played out just didn‚Äôt work for me.

movies.title: F1
movies.reviewText: Still thrilling the second time around. The cinematography on and inside the cars is wild. They‚Äôre not just static either, they pan seamlessly from the road ahead to the driver‚Äôs face. Love Zimmer‚Äôs score too. There‚Äôs not a ton in this movie that‚Äôs not racing. Maybe that‚Äôs to the detriment of the characters but even if you‚Äôre not into racing you still get a thrill watching the characters try and win.

movies.title: Barbarian
movies.reviewText: How are you gonna set a film in Detroit and not put Tim Robinson in it? Revisited this after Weapons. It‚Äôs a solid debut and the first act is great but as it gets weirder it gets less interesting because it leaves less to your imagination.

movies.title: The Fly
movies.reviewText: Incredible body horror classic. Hadn‚Äôt seen it in ages. I forgot how utterly disturbing the last 10 minutes were. Goldblum is perfectly cast as a twitchy nerd fused with a fly, his subtle mannerisms getting more fly-like throughout. For a relatively short movie, it drags at times, particularly all of the 80s obsession dudes had with getting laid. Still, the practical effects are still pretty amazing. A remake these days would probably be all CG and lose all of the magic.

movies.title: The Count of Monte Cristo
movies.reviewText: Had I seen this version first I may have enjoyed the 2024 version a bit less. This version is considerably more streamlined and has a very Hollywood ending. However, I loved the relationship between Dantes and Luis Guzman‚Äôs Jacopo, who is present in the 2024 version but has no lines and the nature of their relationship is never mentioned. I also loved Richard Harris as Abb√© Faria, much more playful in this version. Guy Pierce really chews up the scenery as the main target of Dante‚Äôs‚Äô vengeance, while the other two are relegated to almost footnotes. Also 18-year-old Henry Cavill! This version is great in its own right. I‚Äôd say if you like this version and haven‚Äôt seen the 2024 one, they‚Äôre quite different in style and execution, you might enjoy it as well though.

movies.title: The Count of Monte Cristo
movies.reviewText: I have to confess I‚Äôve never read the book or seen any other adaptation ‚Äî this movie slapped. Beautifully shot with amazing production design. Damn near three hours long though the pace is so brisk you just lose yourself in it. The machinations of the Count‚Äôs revenge are so diabolical I was giddy. The disguises require a bit of suspension of disbelief, but each one was great. Feels like it will reward rewatching. I‚Äôm curious now where this ranks among all the other versions. This one is great.

movies.title: High and Low
movies.reviewText: This movie surprised me at every turn. It starts as almost a stage play before turning into a full-on police procedural. It goes places both literally and figuratively that I wasn‚Äôt expecting. There are some extraordinary touches like a dash of color in an otherwise black and white movie, and the eerie reflection in the kidnapper‚Äôs sunglasses. The ending fell a little flat for me. I guess I‚Äôve been conditioned by modern movies to expect big twist. It felt very Japanese. I can see why Spike‚Äôs remake is getting such tepid reviews. The bar is set pretty high here.

movies.title: The Martian
movies.reviewText: Suggested this to my space-obsessed six-year-old and he loved it. He‚Äôs only ever seen Matt Damon as a stranded astronaut (Interstellar). Just a really solid story about human ingenuity which somehow feels quaint 10 years later. Incredibly deep cast and surprisingly funny. The climactic rescue is pretty thrilling!

movies.title: Eddington
movies.reviewText: A frustratingly bad Coen Brothers ripoff. Tries to satirize the ridiculousness of conservatives and liberals alike during the height of the pandemic in such a ham-fisted way, it‚Äôs unclear what the movie is even trying to say. In the last 15 minutes things happen but it‚Äôs not entirely clear why or what any of it means. It‚Äôs wild that Pedro Pascal is in damn near everything this year but hardly in those things at the same time. Here again, like Materialists, he‚Äôs pretty much wasted.

movies.title: TRON: Legacy
movies.reviewText: This sequel looks gorgeous but maybe a little too pristine. Part of the charm of the first Tron was that the effects were scrappy. The change makes sense thematically but is undercut by the jarring uncanny valley of Clu, a digitized and de-aged Jeff Bridges. They should have leaned more into the imperfection. The plot is pretty nonsensical, not that the first one was incredible either. Bridges seems like he‚Äôs in full Lebowski mode here minus the laughs. The music and the aesthetic really carry this, but also show the beginnings of a style that Kosinski would go on to hone in Oblivion, Top Gun: Maverick, and F1.

movies.title: Weapons
movies.reviewText: Went to a SOLD OUT screening on a Tuesday night. I can‚Äôt remember the last time I was at a sold out show, much less on a Tuesday. An incredible communal experience seldom had anymore. This movie is remarkable. Easily my favorite horror movie in ages. I can‚Äôt say much without spoiling it but suffice it to say, you should check this out in the theater while you can. Great cast, darkly funny and plays on so many of our current phobias in a really effective way. My jaw was on the floor as the credits rolled. If it wasn‚Äôt the last show I may have gotten right back in line for another ticket.

movies.title: Tron
movies.reviewText: Haven‚Äôt seen this since I was a kid. The story is not that great but wow, it‚Äôs visually breathtaking even all these years later. Apparently this wasn‚Äôt nominated for any visual effects awards because they thought using computers was cheating? How quaint. Oddly prescient about the dangers of giving computers control and their applications for making ridiculous sums of money. Never saw the sequel but with the third coming I thought I‚Äôd revisit these.

movies.title: Together
movies.reviewText: Talk about the beast with two backs. Yikes.

movies.title: House of Games
movies.reviewText: A slow burn with really stilted dialog but, boy, when this thing gets going it‚Äôs great. Kept me guessing until the end.

movies.title: Medium Cool
movies.reviewText: A fascinating time capsule of late 1960s Chicago, mixing documentary footage with actors and a narrative. I‚Äôm not sure the narrative part works, particularly the ending, but the idea is pretty bold. Highlights the city of Chicago with an authenticity few films have matched. Tracy Letts picked this in The Big Picture‚Äôs live Chicago movie draft, along with a few others I haven‚Äôt seen. Also stars Peter Bonerz. Great name.

movies.title: The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad!
movies.reviewText: One of my all-time favorite comedies. I‚Äôve probably seen it dozens of times, though not for many years. It still holds up, with jokes and gags coming at such a dizzying pace it seems like you pick up something new each time you watch it. Nielsen is so great, delivering even the dumbest of lines with deadpan gravitas. Even though I haven‚Äôt seen this in forever I was still able to remember damn near every line.

movies.title: The Naked Gun
movies.reviewText: Pales in comparison to the original. Even though it‚Äôs roughly the same runtime, it seems like it only lasted an hour. Neeson is inspired casting, especially if you‚Äôve seen him on Life‚Äôs Too Short, but the script doesn‚Äôt give him much to work with. Pamela Anderson is also great, she really goes for it. I almost wish this were longer so we could get more Paul Walter Hauser as Drebin‚Äôs partner. There‚Äôs definitely some funny moments but I‚Äôd be hard pressed to recall any great lines, even less than an hour after getting out of the theater. This movie somehow made me reassess my rating of Happy Gilmore 2.

movies.title: The Counselor
movies.reviewText: Some things are greater than the sum of their parts. The Counselor is, well, the opposite of that. On paper, a Ridley Scott film written by Cormac McCarthy and starring this A-List cast seems like a sure fire hit. But what we get instead is a bunch of memorable scenes intercut with lots of talk about sex, and not in an interesting way. Half of the characters are like something out of a GTA game and the dialogue is so heavy-handed it doesn‚Äôt make sense coming out of these characters, even when it‚Äôs delivered by great actors. The whole thing adds up to very little because it seems the characters fall victim to their own actions which are only alluded to during the course of the movie, and their fates don‚Äôt really feel justified based on the plot of the movie. It‚Äôs just all so very random. But damn, Checkov‚Äôs Bolito.

movies.title: Prince of Darkness
movies.reviewText: Sorry but I just don‚Äôt find a bunch of grad students in khaki pants all that scary. This is one of Carpenter‚Äôs 80s movies that I somehow missed. Feels like a mashup of some of his previous work. The first hour is dreadfully dull but once the juice is loose, so to speak, things get interesting with some fun body horror and practical effects. This movie could explain why evangelicals are so opposed to higher education.

movies.title: Happy Gilmore 2
movies.reviewText: There‚Äôs no reason for this sequel to exist besides the fact that Netflix dropped a boatload of money on Sandler. Despite that, this movie is a ton of fun. The plot is even thinner than the first but the sheer amount of jokes and cameos keep things interesting. Nearly all of the characters from 30 years ago make an appearance in some way (even the dead ones) and nearly all of them have offspring perfect for stunt casting. If, like me, you watched the original a bunch of times on VHS or cable TV in college, you‚Äôll get a kick out of this.

movies.title: Mississippi Burning
movies.reviewText: Near the end of Mississippi Burning, Willem Dafoe‚Äôs FBI Agent Ward says, ‚ÄúAnyone‚Äôs guilty who watches this happen and pretends it isn‚Äôt.‚Äù As tough as the movie is to watch, some degree of justice is served at the end. But sadly enough, the guilty are now in the highest offices, inflicting greater wounds on larger swaths of people that aren‚Äôt like them. This was made some thirty years after the events depicted and now, 60 years on we haven‚Äôt done much better. This might be up there for Hackman‚Äôs greatest roles. The antithesis of his character in Unforgiven. Dafoe is also great as his partner, and there‚Äôs a slew of ‚Äúthat guy‚Äù to be found on both sides of the law. This movie is near perfect if only it had given its black characters as much depth and dialogue as it does its white characters. It‚Äôs left up to a bunch of white FBI agents to save the day which, in retrospect, seems highly implausible.

movies.title: The Fantastic Four: First Steps
movies.reviewText: The bar for recent Marvel movies is pretty low, and even lower for Fantastic Four movies, so I was pleasantly surprised how much I enjoyed this. I loved the retro-future aesthetic (spotted one of Chicago‚Äôs iconic Marina Towers at one point) and the chemistry between all the members was great and believable. This is the first Marvel movie in forever where it didn‚Äôt feel like you needed to do homework to follow the story, and they weren‚Äôt adding a bunch of storylines to set up the next thing. There‚Äôs no glowing MacGuffin and the stakes are both high and personal. F4 definitely feels like a spiritual companion to this summer‚Äôs Superman, which is similarly colorful and hope-filled. But I‚Äôd feel more comfortable taking my 3- and 6-year-old to F4 than Superman, which has a few moments that are a little too mature for younger kids.

movies.title: Vanishing Point
movies.reviewText: This movie is a real vibe. The first half is great ‚Äî mostly driving with an occasional flashback to a time Kowalski saw a titty ‚Äî but the more people talked, the less I enjoyed it. This movie feels like it had a lot to say but I‚Äôm not sure I got it. Great cinematography. Lots of wide angle shots of the desert and mountains. I imagine this was pretty influential, with shades of Blues Brothers, Mad Max, Drive, and even Do the Right Thing. Also, Charlotte Rampling. Wowsa.

movies.title: Tremors
movies.reviewText: Haven‚Äôt seen this in ages but it‚Äôs fun as hell. Great chemistry between Kevin Bacon and Fred Ward, clever use of practical effects, and some delightful Raimi-esque shots. A perfect blend of comedy and creature horror. Sad that we‚Äôll never see a movie where Fred Ward plays Jon Bernthal‚Äôs dad.

movies.title: The Beach
movies.reviewText: Imagine being so entitled to think you could just take up residence on the other side of a Thai island inhabited by armed weed farmers without consequences. Anyway, I missed this when it came out and only recently realized it was a Boyle/Garland joint. And much like Sunshine and, to a lesser extent, 28 Days/Years Later, it starts off with a strong premise before going completely off the rails. Leo and Tilda had not quite reached their primes but still made this highly watchable, even if it‚Äôs kind of a mess. Everything held up pretty well except the internet cafe filled with iMacs with their default homepage set to Excite.

movies.title: Bring Her Back
movies.reviewText: Well that was deeply disturbing. I‚Äôve seen some shit but this movie had me looking away at several points. Buncha fuckin‚Äô sickos made this movie and I kinda loved it. Sally Hawkins is great, though I will never be able to watch her in anything else and not think of this movie. Sick fucks, I tell ya.

movies.title: M3GAN 2.0
movies.reviewText: I had a great time with this. Goes full T2 with hilarious results. I was straight up cackling at several points. Not sure how they‚Äôll be able to one up this for the inevitable third movie.

movies.title: Only Lovers Left Alive
movies.reviewText: Loved this slow-burn, kinda punk rock vampire film. Exceptionally cool hanging out with Hiddleston and Swinton as an old vampire couple. Great supporting cast as well. Feels like a fresh take on the vampire genre, which is saying a lot in a year where Sinners came out. Haven‚Äôt seen a ton of Jarmusch‚Äôs films but what I have seen are usually a good hang and this is no exception.

movies.title: The Phoenician Scheme
movies.reviewText: After Asteroid City I wasn‚Äôt sure I‚Äôd ever watch another Wes Anderson movie. His whole shtick of what I described in my review of that movie as ‚Äúa bunch of (mostly) white famous people saying words in meticulously crafted shots‚Äù has worn pretty thin. But I found this to be pretty entertaining, largely thanks to the trio of actors in the lead roles, particularly Michael Cera, who steals every scene he‚Äôs in. There are several laugh out loud moments, even if the plot is completely nonsensical.

movies.title: Perfect Days
movies.reviewText: More like Perfect Movie, amirite? I, too, just want to read books, listen to tapes and not worry about the rise of fascism while I clean a toilet for the hundredth time this week.

movies.title: The Batman
movies.reviewText: I was compelled to watch this after Superman. The Batman is the antithesis of modern superhero movies. I don‚Äôt know how they will incorporate Batman into Gunn‚Äôs new DCU but it almost certainly won‚Äôt be this Batman. Where Snyder seemingly took Superman into the dark, Gunn seems certain to bring Batman into the light. I miss when things could just be a thing and didn‚Äôt have to spawn endless sequels or crossover with every other IP owned by a megacorp. That said, I‚Äôm looking forward to The Batman 2. lol

movies.title: Superman
movies.reviewText: I am admittedly not a DC comics guy. But Superman (1978) was one of the first movies I ever saw in the theater and it left a lasting impression on me. None of the Superman movies or shows since have come close to giving me that same sense of wonder. So my expectations going into James Gunn‚Äôs take were pretty low. And this is pretty much what I expected it to be. Lighter and more fun than the Snyder films, but overstuffed with characters and quips. There‚Äôs sooooo many characters here. From the room full of tech dweebs that work for Luthor to the staff of the Daily Planet, many of whom add little to the story outside of Lois (and Jimmy‚Äôs bizarre connection to Luthor). Corenswet strikes a great balance of earnestness and playfulness, and his chemistry with Brosnahan‚Äôs Lois worked well. But there was just so much other stuff going on. The nascent Justice League is shoehorned in to setup future DCU installments, only adding to the glut of characters. Not a bad movie by any stretch but it just felt like a missed opportunity to have a bigger take on what it means to be Superman in 2025, where having empathy is considered either ‚Äúwoke‚Äù or punk rock, depending on your perspective.

movies.title: Heads of State
movies.reviewText: Fun cast, terrible script. Some fun action scenes but, as Idris Elba says, ‚ÄúI prefer real cinema.‚Äù

movies.title: I'm Still Here
movies.reviewText: A remarkable film. As Americans we like to think something like this could never happen here, but it already is. This film serves as a necessary and dire warning. Brave performance from Fernanda Torres, whose character Eunice says to the press, ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs necessary to compensate the families, and do the most important thing, clarify and judge all crimes committed during the dictatorship. If that doesn‚Äôt happen, they will continue to be committed with impunity.‚Äù Hoping I live to see this happen in the U.S.

movies.title: Lethal Weapon
movies.reviewText: Not sure this 80s smash hit holds up very well. The action is ok but it‚Äôs really the chemistry between Glover (who was 10 years younger than I am now when he was ‚Äútoo old for this shit‚Äù) and Gibson that makes the movie. Gary Busey is woefully miscast as the lead henchman who dukes it out in a blurry mess of a hand-to-hand combat scene with Gibson in the climax. The plot is pretty incomprehensible, even by 80s standards. Some fun writing by Shane Black though not on the level of Kiss Kiss Bang Bang or The Nice Guys. Overall kind of a disappointing rewatch.

movies.title: I'm Gonna Git You Sucka
movies.reviewText: I‚Äôm Gonna Git You Sucka holds a special place in my heart. My best friend Eldridge, who passed away last year, introduced me to it in high school. My friends and I must have watched it dozens of times. Even all these years later I can practically recite the whole thing. Plus it paved the way for In Living Color, in which many of the cast here would go on to star. This is a brilliant spoof of blaxploitation films in the same vein as Airplane and The Naked Gun, and arguably as funny or funnier than either of those movies. Shoutout to legendary costume designer Ruth E. Carter, whose incredible work here adds so much to the humor.

movies.title: Sneakers
movies.reviewText: In hindsight, Cosmo was right.

movies.title: Waves
movies.reviewText: This movie still hits hard on my third watch several years after its release. I connected with it on so many levels ‚Äî as a parent, a son, a husband. This is essentially two movies, one about a brother and the other about his sister, divided by a twist of fate. The two halves feel very different but vital to each other. The color in this film is so vibrant. The performances are exquisite and vulnerable, particularly the two young leads. I really wish this were available in 4K. This might be one of my all-time top 10 films.

movies.title: Point Blank
movies.reviewText: This movie goes harder than it needed to for a pretty standard revenge flick. The pace is dizzying, so much happens in just 91 minutes, but it takes its time with some great shots along the way. Lee Marvin is a stoic badass. No doubt this influenced a ton of great modern crime films.

movies.title: F1
movies.reviewText: F1 is like a summer blockbuster designed in a lab. Hits all the right notes, looks incredible, and delivers thrills, even if some of the beats are cliched and the character development is a bit shallow. Whatever this movie cost it is all on the screen. The racing scenes are plentiful and feel as immersive as the flying scenes in Kosinski‚Äôs Top Gun: Maverick. Pitt is great here, but the rest of the cast deserves credit for carving out distinct characters with very little screen time. By the end of the film you feel like part of the team, sharing the victory with them. Exhilarating.
